age: 55. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___

Fatigue
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Bone Marrow biopsy 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M w/ PMH of AIDS p/w 1 month of fatigue, anemia and 
increased diarhea. Pt. stopped taking his ARV's about 15 mo ago 
and was feeling healthy up until about 1 month ago except for 
RLQ abdominal pain which has been present for about one year.  
Since early ___ he has been having ___ loose stools per day, he 
says that they are not bloody or melanotic. His fatigue is 
difficult to characterize, he has no focal weakness and is able 
to walk up the 3 flights of stairs at work w/o getting "winded", 
but he does say that he has just become a couch potato in the 
last month. His abdominal pain is localized to a small area in 
his RLQ and has been constant for the past year, it is worse 
when he eats cold foods, but is not associated w/ defecation. 
Pt. also reports a 20lb wt. loss in the last month.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH:  
1. HIV+, diagnosed ___. PCP, ___  
3. KS, treated and in remission, ___  
4. gonorrheae, ___. ___, most recent infection ___, treated with  
fluconazole  
6. AVN, R hip s/p R hip replacement in ___. nephrolithiasis due to indinavir requiring hospitalization  
8. h/o depression and situational depression  
9. Hepatitis B, ___  
10. PCP ___ (by symptoms and CXR, but DFA negative) and treated  

11. dvt in lue from ___  
12. Syphillis ___
13. CVA ___ in ___

___

father: emphysema and bladder cancer

vitals: 99.1, 81, 105/63, 16, 95% RA
gen: cachectic appearing, comfortable, NAD
heent: Conjunctival pallor, hard white plaques on sides of 
tongue, multiple umbillicated papules on L side of face in beard 
line, also a few on R side of face.
pulm: CTAB
cv: RRR, No MRG
abd: ND, BS+, No HSM, only tender in 3x3cm area of RLQ, no 
rebound. Scars from previous surgery.
extr: Thin, peripheral pulses strong.
neuro: A/O X3, CNII-XII intact. Strength ___ and equal in arm 
flex/ex, finger flex/ex, hip flex/ex, knee flex/ex, 
dorsiflexion/plantarflexion.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:00PM BLOOD WBC-6.2 RBC-2.44* Hgb-6.1* Hct-20.4* 
MCV-84 MCH-25.0* MCHC-29.8* RDW-18.9* Plt ___

Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-SM Urobiln-12* pH-7.0 Leuks-NEG
___ 08:43AM URINE Hours-RANDOM Creat-42 Na-149
___ 08:43AM URINE Osmolal-453

Blood Cultures routine and mycolytic NGTD at time of D/C

CXR:  In comparison with study of ___, there is no change or 
evidence of 
acute cardiopulmonary disease. Specifically, no focal pneumonia 
or 
interstitial prominence to suggest PCP. 

U/S liver: 
1. Thickened gallbladder wall with no gallstones. Thick-walled 
bile ducts 
with no biliary dilatation. The appearance of these structures 
is consistent 
with HIV choliangiopathy. 
2. Focal fat seen within the liver.  
3. Mild splenomegaly. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M w/ AIDS off HAART for 15 months presents w/ malaise, 
anemia.
.
#HIV: Pt. has had poor reactions to ARV Tx in the past (stopped 
taking because of nausea w/ ritonavir), pt. restarted on ARV w/ 
attention to this. Pt. did well w/ no N/V after taking ritonavir 
at HS. Blood cultures were drawn for bacteria, mycobacteria and 
fungi and were no growth to date on day of D/C. Continued 
dapsone ppx, but considered switching to atovaquone because of 
hemolytic anemia, Hct remained stable so we kept pt. on dapsone.

.
#Abdominal pain: Pt. has Hx of bowel wall ulcer, this seems 
probable as his tenderness is extremely localized, has not been 
progressive. Likely he does not have acute bacterial issue as he 
is non septic and this has been present for a long time. He has 
been scoped before w/ conflicting path results (negative CMV Cx 
but a few inclusions),consider CMV colitis, Consider HSV 
colitis, Consider parasitic ___. Dr. ___ 
performed the endoscopy felt that the ulcer looked like it was 
from CMV and so pt. was empirically started on IV gancyclovir 
and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir after 2 days. The 
abdominal pain seemed to improve slightly day to day. Pt. had 
elevated alk phos, GGT, Tbili so liver U/S was performed and wet 
read was consistent w/ HIV cholangiopathy.
.
#Anemia: Appears to be hemolytic as haptoglobin was decreased to 
<20 and retic count is elevated. Elevated retic count (not 
appropriately elevated given low Hbg) suggests that there is a 
lack of production. He recieved 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct 
increased to above 25 and remained stable after transfusion, on 
day of d/c was 24.9. Likely that he is no longer hemolyzing, but 
unknown whether his marrow is responding at time of d/c. There 
was significant concern that the lack of marrow response 
represented a marrow infiltrative process so a BMB was obtained. 
Results of BMB were pending at D/C.
.
#Fever: Likely OI as pt. has no other focal signs of infection. 
Could be drug fever as pt. recently started on gancyclovir and 
ARV's, the fevers did not appear until the night after the 
gancyclovir was started and continued to wax and wane and he had 
a temperature to 100.8 the night before d/c. CXR, UA, Ucx, Blood 
Cx X3 sets routine Negative so far. Pt. to f/u w/ Dr. ___ 
results of BMB and mycolytic blood cultures.
.
#Fatigue: likely ___ anemia, but may also be due to chronic OI 
and/or HIV wasting syndrome as pt. appeared quite cachectic. 
Nutrition was consulted and recommended ensure supplementation, 
but pt. did not like ensure and made this clear to nutrition, 
ensure was seen unopened on pt.s tray every morning.
.
#Diarrhea: Likely ___ OI, differential is quite wide: crypto, 
giardia, ___, CMV, C. diff. All previous wkup 
was negative in ___.  Likely etiology is an OI which will be 
treated by increasing his CD4 count. Repeat stool studies were 
negative for o/p, ___, crypto, giardia, cyclospora.
.
#Hyponatremia: Possibly secondary to diarrhea with free water 
replacement or SIADH from chronic pain. Most likelly from 
diarrhea. Urine lytes, Cr, Osm inconclusive for SIADH vs. volume 
depletion. FeNa was 1.6. Pt. remained asymptomatic and recieved 
no specific treatment.
.
#Elevated alk phos: Likely bile duct source as GGT also 
elevated. Pt. also complaining of RUQ pain and tenderness, has 
previous history of U/S which showed cholelithiasis. Liver U/S 
did not show stones in duct, wet read was consistent with HIV 
cholangiopathy.

 
Medications on Admission:
Dapsone 100mg QD
Albuterol 2 puffs PRN

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Dapsone 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Emtricitabine-Tenofovir 200-300 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Atazanavir 150 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Ritonavir 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Valganciclovir 450 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
6. Albuterol Sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
Two (2) Puffs Inhalation PRN as needed for shortness of breath 
or wheezing.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary
Hemolytic anemia.
bone marrow dysfunction
HIV
Chronic diarrhea

secondary
Depression

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have been diagnosed with hemolytic anemia and inappropriate 
bone marrow response. The results of some tests as to the cause 
are still pending. The results of your bone marrow biopsy are 
also pending. Please follow up with Dr. ___ the results 
of your tests. We were not able to find the cause of your 
chronic diarrhea although cytomegalovirus is suspected and you 
are being treated with valgancyclovir 900mg twice daily.

Please take all of your medications exactley as prescribed.

Please return to the emergency department if you experience any 
worsening fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, 
confusion, bleeding, black tarry stools, fatigue or any other 
concerning symptoms.

Please make a follow up appointment with Dr. ___ ___ 
within one week. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 55-year-old male with a chief complaint of fatigue. He has a history of AIDS, diagnosed 15 months prior, and has been off antiretroviral therapy (ARV) for 15 months. He presents with anemia, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, which has been present for a year. He has a history of depression, situational depression, and has experienced weight loss. His physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, hard white plaques on the sides of his tongue, and multiple umbilicated papules on his face. His laboratory results show anemia, elevated liver enzymes, and hyponatremia. He was started on IV gancyclovir and then transitioned to PO valgancyclovir for suspected CMV colitis. He received 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct increased to above 25. He was also started on dapsone prophylaxis. His discharge medications include dapsone 100mg QD and valgancyclovir. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is an ___ lady, speaking only ___, with 
___ gastric cancer (diagnosed ___, currently on ramucirumab 
alone (held following surgery) and arthritis, who presented with 
a hip fracture after a fall from standing height.  

===ACUTE ISSUES=== 
#Hip fracture:  
#s/p Fall:  
Presented after a fall from standing height and found to have a 
right intertrochanteric hip fracture with varus angulation. CT 
head with subgaleal hematoma but no intracranial hemorrhage, and 
CT C spine negative for traumatic injury. Fall appears to be 
purely mechanical secondary to underlying neuropathy and 
progressive weakness with possible acute decompensation in the 
setting of pneumonia. She had no LOC, but may have an 
orthostatic component as well contributing to lightheadedness 
given poor PO intake. Troponins obtained for pre-op workup were 
slightly elevated x3 (max 0.03). Likely ___ slight ___, EKGs w/o 
e/o MI. 

The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service with 
a right hip fracture. The patient was taken to the operating 
room on ___ for right hip ORIF, which the patient tolerated 
well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient worked with ___ who 
determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weight-bearing as tolerated in the right lower extremity, and 
will be discharged on ___ for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will 
follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was 
had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected 
post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or 
return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The 
patient was also given written instructions concerning 
precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. 
The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
#LLL pneumonia: CXR obtained on pre-op workup showed LLL 
opacity. Unclear if she had a true clinical pneumonia given she 
so did not have symptoms of pneumonia, but fall could be due to 
weakness in the setting of infection. Did not meet criteria for 
HAP. Treated with five day course of ceftriaxone and 
azithromycin. 
 
===CHRONIC ISSUES===
#Gastric cancer: 
Diagnosed ___. Treated with 5 cycles on folfox, followed by 
taxol/ramucirumab for 5 cycles (C5 D1 and ___. Seen by 
oncologist Dr. ___ on ___ who recommended stopping 
taxol and proceeding with ramucirumab alone due to concerns that 
the taxol was causing worsening neuropathy and interfering with 
her quality of life. Of note, ramucirumab was held following her 
operation. Will need outpatient evaluation and discussion of 
goals of care to determine further treatment course. In 
addition, patient had therapeutic paracentesis while inpatient 
on ___.

#GERD: Continued home omeprazole BID.  
#Hypertension: Held spironolactone given elevated creatinine at 
___ initially, restarted on ___.
#Depression: Held home citalopram for prolonged QTc. Lower dose 
may be safer for age.  
#Overactive bladder: Held home fesoterodine as was 
non-formulary.

===TRANSITIONAL ISSUES===
[]monitor QTc, was prolong when patient came into hospital 
(500+), held zofran and citalopram

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

1.  Heparin 5000 UNIT SC BID Duration: 4 Weeks

11.  travoprost 0.004 % ophthalmic QHS  
12. HELD- Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY  This medication was held. 
Do not restart Citalopram until follow up with primary care 
provider.

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
right hip inter-trochanteric fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated on right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take subcutaneous heparin daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with Dr. ___ in the ___ Trauma 
Clinic ___ days post-operation for evaluation. Please call 
___ to schedule appointment.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

Please follow up with your oncologist at your earliest 
convenience.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext||The patient is an 88-year-old female who was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service with a right hip fracture after a fall from standing height. She has a history of gastric carcinoma, currently undergoing chemotherapy, and has undergone left ORIF of the hip. She presents with right hip pain and right intra-trochanteric fracture. The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis, vertigo, arthritis, coronary artery disease, and syncope. She has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

The patient underwent a right hip open reduction and internal fixation procedure, which she tolerated well. She was given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was discharged on oral medications, including antibiotics and anticoagulation, and was advised to follow up with her doctor routine. She was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care.

The patient's diagnosis is a right hip fracture, and she will require ongoing management and follow-up care to ensure proper healing and recovery. ||endoftext||

including alcohol and amitriptyline for suicide attempt, with 
possible aspirin and Paxil. She had stopped her Paxil several 
weeks prior. She was treated with bicarbonate drip for TCA 
toxicity with the amitriptyline. ECGs were stable without signs 
of TCA toxicity. There was concern for serotonin syndrome given 
initial tachycardia and clonus. She was stable and extubated and 
weaned to room air. She was seen by Psychiatry and placed on 
___ with 1:1 sitter. There was ___ evidence of any further 
toxicity and she medically ready for transfer to Psychiatry. Her 
amitriptyline was stopped.

history of withdrawal seizures or delirium tremens. This most 
recent intoxication precipitated depression leading to the 
suicide attempt. She was treated with diazepam and CIWA for 
alcohol withdrawal. She was treated with folic acid, thiamine, 
multivitamin.

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 23-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital after an intentional overdose of amitriptyline and alcohol. She had a history of previous suicide attempts, self-harm, and eating disorder. Her presenting symptoms included altered mental status, tachycardia, and clonus. Laboratory results showed elevated levels of amitriptyline, ethanol, and acetaminophen, but negative for benzodiazepines and barbiturates. The patient was treated with a bicarbonate drip for TCA toxicity and was extubated and weaned to room air. She was also treated for possible serotonin syndrome and aspirin overdose. The patient's medications at discharge included none, as her amitriptyline was stopped. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have fracture of the left hip, and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on ___ for ORIF with TFN, which the patient 
tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. 

After the procedure the patient was taken from the OR to the 
PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from 
anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was 
initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and 
progressed to a regular diet and oral medications. The patient 
was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per 
routine. The patient's home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The ___ hospital course 
was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weight bearing as tolerated in the left lower extremity, and 
will be discharged on Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The patient 
will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough 
discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the 
office or return to the hospital, and all questions were 
answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- weight bearing as tolerated and range of motion as tolerated 
in left lower extremity 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

PAIN MEDICATIONS INSTRUCTIONS:
1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock.
2)  Add your prescribed narcotics as needed for increased pain. 
Start weaning the narcotic medication once you get home. 

This is an example on how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.

3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please continue home Xarelto daily

WOUND CARE:
- Your incision is covered with a dry dressing. Please change 
the dressing daily. If there is no drainage, you may leave your 
incision open to the air. If you are continuing to have 
drainage, you may place a dry dressing over the incision as 
needed.
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB

Physical Therapy:
weight bearing as tolerated and range of motion as tolerated in 
left lower extremity 

Activity:  Out of bed w/ assist 
Ambulate twice daily if patient able
 Right lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
 Left lower extremity:  Full weight bearing
Encourage turning, deep breathing and coughing qhour when awake. 
 

Treatments Frequency:
Any staples or superficial sutures you have are to remain in 
place for at least 2 weeks postoperatively.  Incision may be 
left open to air unless actively draining.  If draining, you may 
apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape.  You may shower 
and allow water to run over the wound, but please refrain from 
bathing for at least 4 weeks postoperatively.

Call your surgeon's office with any questions.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext||The patient is an 89-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a left intertrochanteric fracture after falling from standing and landing on her left hip. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, mild COPD, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. She is allergic to sulfa, dicloxacillin, and Bactrim. The patient underwent left hip ORIF with TFN and was discharged with a diagnosis of left intertrochanteric hip fracture. She was prescribed medications including Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis, and was instructed to take Tylenol and narcotics as needed for pain. She was also advised to continue her home medications, except for those that were adjusted during her hospital stay. The patient was discharged in stable condition, with her incision well approximated and dressing clean and dry. She was instructed to follow up with her surgeon and to take her medications as prescribed. ||endoftext||

The patient is a ___ year old gentleman with a history of AVR and 
aortic aneurysm repair, L CFA-axillary bypass graft ___ and R 
femoral to axillary bypass PFTE graft ___ admitted with right 
groin wound dehiscence and S. anginosus and MSSA bacteremia with 
course c/b rupture of a mycotic aneurysm at his femoral graft 
site. 

VASCULAR: Right groin wound was packed, and patient was started 
on vancomycin, Cipro, and Flagyl and admitted to the vascular 
surgery service. Admission blood cultures grew strep anginosus 
and wound swab was polymicrobial including MSSA and e Coli. CT 
angiogram was concerning for infection at the site of bypass 
graft anastamosis with the femoral artery. ID was consulted, who 
recommended transition to Zosyn. Pt was then pre-oped and 
consented for surgery for infected right femoral axillary 
bypass. Coumadin was stopped in preperation of surgery. He was 
on a heparin drip for his mechanical valve. 

CTA: 
  
1. Widely patent right axillary to femoral bypass graft, with 
minimal soft 
tissue density and small locules of air surrounding the distal 
portion of the 
bypass graft at its femoral artery anastomotic site. Although, 
no drainable 
fluid collections or abscesses are seen, this would be 
concerning for 
infection in the presence of clinical symptoms. 
  
2. Stable appearance of the ascending thoracic aortic graft and 
widely patent 
left axillary to femoral bypass graft. Normal appearance of the 
abdominal 
aorta and its major visceral branches. 
  
3. Unchanged appearance of an isodense right lower pole renal 
lesion and 
multiple indeterminate left renal lesions since the earlier 
study. These can 
be further evaluated by renal CTA protocol if this has not 
evaluated before. 

He was taken to the OR after developing several small bleeds 
from his operative site concerning for herald bleeds from a 
ruptured aneurysm. In the OR on ___ he was found to have fresh 
clotted blood at his femoral graft site with concern for a 
disrupted femoral anastomosis. He was found to have inflammatory 
changes in his retroperitoneum and a large inflammatory phlegmon 
at his rectus. The distal portion of his axillofemoral graft was 
detached and a saphenous vein graft was placed. 

___ - Exploration of right groin, control of the external iliac 
artery via a retroperitoneal exposure, excision of distal 
portion of the axillary-femoral bypass,
and vein patch repair of the femoral artery with saphenous vein 
patch.

Patient remained intubated on return from OR

Due to his massive bleeding and transfusion requirements, he 
developed abdominal compartment syndrome overnight and was taken 
back to the OR on ___ for exploration of retroperitoneal space, 
washout of retroperitoneal space and intra abdominal cavity, 
packing of the retroperitoneum with Ioban closure of the 
abdominal incision which was left open. 

___ - Exploration of retroperitoneal space, washout of

MSSA as well as mixed flora. A CT Torso on ___ showed "a widely 
patent right axillary to femoral bypass graft, with minimal soft 
tissue density and small locules of air surrounding the distal 
portion of the bypass graft at its femoral artery anastomotic 
site." A TEE was performed showed "a well-seated bi-leaflet 
mechanical aortic valve prosthesis with normal leaflet motion 
and gradients. No discrete vegetations." 

The patient was treated with piperacillin-tazobactam for 
coverage of S. anginosus and MSSA BSI as well as a polymicrobial 
wound infection. 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible.

also encouraged. Lasix was discontinued and ___ should not be 
restarted until creatinine at baseline. VAC was also 
discontinued and  should continue on wet to dry BID until follow 
up. Foley was reinserted for urinary retention of approx 600 cc 
urine. Please attempt voiding trial in a day or so. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, 
voiding with foley, and pain was well controlled.

Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Lower Extremity Surgery Discharge Instructions

What to expect when you go home:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated

3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
You should gradually increase your activity
You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed 

What to report to office:
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

||startoftext||The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted with a right groin infection. He has a history of multiple medical problems, including a previous stroke, ascending aortic aneurysm, and severe hypertension. He was treated with antibiotics and instructed to follow up with vascular surgery, but his wound continued to worsen and he was readmitted to the hospital. 

The patient underwent several surgical procedures, including exploration of the right groin, control of the external iliac artery, and excision of the distal portion of the axillary-femoral bypass. He also underwent abdominal washout, packing removal, and temporary abdominal closure. 

The patient's diagnosis was a right groin infection, and he was found to have a polymicrobial infection including Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus anginosus, and Escherichia coli. He was prescribed antibiotics, including ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and gentamicin. 

The patient's medications at discharge included ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and gentamicin. He also had an allergy to oxycodone. ||endoftext||

Discharge Diagnosis:
Frozen Preliminary: Medulloblastoma 
Right cerebellar mass 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Tumor

Surgery
You underwent surgery to remove a brain lesion from your 
brain. 

Frozen preliminary was: Medulloblastoma
Please keep your incision dry until your staples are removed. 
You may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

___
target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 28-year-old male who was admitted to the Neurosurgery service with a chief complaint of headache, neck pain, and numbness in his left fingers. He had a history of knee surgery and wisdom teeth removal. He was allergic to amoxicillin. The patient presented with a progressively worsening headache, neck pain, and numbness in his left fingers over the last three weeks. He was transferred to the hospital from another emergency room and was found to have a right cerebellar mass on CT head. The patient underwent a suboccipital craniotomy for tumor resection and was diagnosed with a possible medulloblastoma, hemangioblastoma, or metastasis. At discharge, the patient was comfortable, oriented, and had normal neurological function. He was prescribed medications for pain control and was scheduled for follow-up appointments. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
It has been a privilege to take care of you ___ 
___.
.
You were hospitalized because your heart was beating very slowly 
because of an abnormality in the electrical wiring system of 
your heart; you have a condition known as complete heart block.
.
You underwent an emergency procedure to implant a pacemaker into 
your chest that provides your heart with a regular electrical 
current to ensure that it beats at the correct rhythm. You 
tolerated the procedure well and the pacemaker is functioning 
correctly. This pacemaker will hopefully help to prevent 
recurrence of the fatigue that you have been experiencing.
.
You should avoid raising your arms above your head, and should 
also avoid heavy lifting, for the next several weeks.  Do not 
remove the steri-strips over the site where the pacemaker was 
placed.

Implantation of a pacemaker is surgical procedure, which is why 
you will require antibiotics to prevent infections. The 
following is your antibiotic regimen:
# START: Clindamycin 300 mg every 6h for 1 day
.
Otherwise, your heart regimen is unchanged. Your current heart 
regimen is the following:
# CONTINUE: Torsemide 60 mg twice daily
# CONTINUE: Lisinopril 10 mg daily
# CONTINUE: Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg sublingual tablet as needed for 
CP
**Take up to 3 tablets 5 minutes apart then call ___ if pain 
does not resolve.**
# CONTINUE: Cholestyramine 4 gram packet daily
# CONTINUE: Ezetimibe 10 mg daily
.
We decreased the dose of your Gabapentin to 300mg daily. This 
dose is based on your kidney function levels.  You can discuss 
the dosing with your primary care doctor next week.

Please continue to take all of your other medications as 
previously prescribed. 
.
Please attend the follow-up appointments detailed below.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 57-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with symptoms of syncope and was found to have a high-grade multi-level AV block with a heart rate of 40 beats per minute. She has a history of bradycardia, diastolic congestive heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. She was admitted to the hospital and underwent a pacemaker placement procedure, which was successful. At the time of discharge, she was hemodynamically stable with a heart rate of 40 beats per minute. She was prescribed several medications, including Torsemide, Lisinopril, Cholestyramine, Ezetimibe, ASA, Albuterol Sulfate Nebs, ADVAIR DISKUS, SINGULAIR, Fexofenadine, LORATADINE, and TRAZODON. ||endoftext||

age: 43. gender: F.  
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___

Headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar puncture ___

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ yo F with a history of triple negative BRCA1+ 
breast cancer diagnosed in ___. She underwent bilateral 
mastectomy and chemotherapy at that time. She has been generally 
lost to follow-up but was hospitalized recently for shortness of 
breath and found to have recurrence of her cancer.  
 Body imaging showed extensive probable metastases in the thorax 
with adenopathy and numerous pulmonary nodules as well as some 
left lung segment collapse. She did not have large pleural or 
pericardial effusions. The abdomen was benign including the 
liver. Bone scan, however, showed numerous abnormalities 
suggesting skeletal metastases. Widespread skeletal involvement 
is somewhat uncommon in triple-negative cancers, but the bone 
scan compared to prior scans does show a marked change. Her 
tumor marker is mildly elevated. She has some hoarseness, which 
likely reflects left recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement given 
the high concentration of disease in her left upper chest.  

 She now comes in because reports that she has had a severe 
headache and nausea for the past 48 hours. She reports that she 
has been waking up with a headaches every morning this week; 
however, this headache has persisted since yesterday and has not 
resolved. She reports she has been feeling nauseous and has not 
been able to each much. Reports that today she "vomited up 
bile." She denies dizziness, lightheadedness, or syncope. 
Reports that she has had difficulty seeing out of her L eye and 
"can only see half a word" when she reads.  

 In the ED, she had a head CT that showed:  
 There are multiple intracranial metastatic lesions. A lesion in 
the right occipital lobe best seen on series 602 B image 31 
measures approximately 3.1 x 3.1 cm and is complicated by a 
small amount of intralesional hemorrhage. There is associated 
vasogenic edema. Additional lesions are seen, for example and 
extra-axial lesion on series 2, image 23 abutting the inner 
table of the frontal bone in a left para falcine location. A 
small hyperdense lesion at the left parietal vertex is seen on 
series 2, image 25. A lesion abutting the  
 frontal lobe is seen on series 2, image 13 measuring 
approximately 1.4 x 3.7 cm. There is no midline shift or 
downward herniation though there is asymmetric effacement of 
right cerebral sulci compared to the left.  
 She was evaluated by neurosurgery who recommended Keppra, 
Dexamethasone, keeping SBP<140, and MRI scan.  
 
 On arrival to the floor, patient is tired, but otherwise well 
appearing.  
 REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: A 10 point ROS was performed and was 
otherwise negative.  
 
Past Medical History:
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY  
She initially presented in early ___ with a multicentric 
high-grade triple-negative left breast cancer. The largest focus 
of invasive cancer was 5 cm. There was no lymphovascular 
invasion and her four sentinel lymph nodes sampled at the time 
of mastectomy in ___ were negative. The contralateral 
prophylactic right mastectomy was negative pathologically.  
 BRCA testing showed a BRCA1 mutation.  
 Thus, she had an advanced left breast cancer which was 
multifocal but no lymph node spread while the right breast was 
negative. Following recovery from her mastectomy and her 
bilateral ___ flap reconstructions, a port was inserted and she 
began dose-dense cyclophosphamide and doxorubicin in early ___. She received four doses of dose-dense cyclophosphamide and 
doxorubicin followed by weekly paclitaxel. Dr. ___ was 
consulted, but did not feel that she required post mastectomy 
radiation therapy based on free margins, the absence of 
lymphovascular invasion and the absence of nodal involvement.  
 Following her chemotherapy there was no additional systemic 
therapy given because of her triple-negative status. We did 
strongly encourage her to have a prophylactic bilateral BSO, but 
she opted to defer that following completion of her other 
therapy. In fact, this was never done and she had a long 
interval where she did not ___ for routine followup here.  
 She was recently seen for shortness of breath. Re-staging 
showed recurrent disease.  
 
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
HCV, no prior treatment  
h/o liver failure due to Acetaminophen toxicity  
h/o eating disorder  
 

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother - colon cancer  
Father - ___ Body dementia

CT head w/o contrast ___ IMPRESSION: 
Multiple intracranial lesions concerning for metastatic disease 
with
hemorrhage involving a right occipital lesion.  Additional 
lesions as
described can be better assessed on MRI.

IMPRESSION:  
Extensive metastatic disease in the chest with large left upper 
lobe mass and
innumerable small nodules.  Bibasilar atelectasis, left greater 
than right.

CT head w/o contrast ___ IMPRESSION:
1. Multiple intracranial lesions compatible with metastatic 
disease are again
demonstrated.
2. The largest right occipital parenchymal lesion appears 
stable, with stable
adjacent hemorrhage and stable extensive surrounding edema.
3. Small amount of subacute hemorrhage adjacent to the large 
right frontal
dural-based extra-axial lesion was seen on the preceding MRI, 
but not seen on
the present or prior CTs, due to the subacute phase.
4. No new acute hemorrhage.
5. The right frontal bone lesion contiguous with the right 
frontal extra-axial
mass, which was seen on the preceding MRI, is not visualized by 
CT.

MRI head w/ and w/o contrast ___ IMPRESSION:
1. Numerous enhancing intra and extra-axial supratentorial 
lesions, as
described, consistent with intracranial metastatic disease.  The 
largest of
these lesions is extra-axial in in the left frontal lobe 
measuring up to 42 x
30 mm.  A 38 x 26 mm right occipital lesion demonstrates 
necrosis and cystic
component, with the largest area of adjacent vasogenic edema.  
Almost all the
lesions are hemorrhagic, corresponding to hyperdensities seen on 
CT.
2. Irregular enhancement of the calvarium adjacent to the 
bifrontal
extra-axial lesions suggesting osseous involvement.
3. Additional 10 mm enhancing focus within the left occipital 
calvarium,
suggestive of additional focus of osseous involvement.

ECHO ___ 
IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Hyperdynamic left 
ventricular systolic function. No pathologic valvular flow. LVEF 
75%. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ old woman with multicentric 
high-grade triple-negative BRCA1+ left breast cancer dx in ___, 
s/p bilateral mastectomy and treatment with cyclophosphamide, 
doxorubicin, and paclitaxel in ___, who presented with 
headache. CT of her head demonstrated multiple intracranial 
lesions concerning for metastasis, with hemorrhage in a R 
occipital lesion. Radiation-oncology, Neuro-oncology, and 
Neurosurgery were consulted. No role for surgery, althogh the 
patient was started on dexamethasone and levetiracetam. Repeat 
NCHCT without acute changes. She had an MRI which showed 
numerous enhancing intra and extra-axial supratentorial lesions 
with hemorrhagic component, consistent with intracranial 
metastatic disease. The largest of these lesions is extra-axial 
in in the left frontal lobe measuring up to 42 x 30 mm. The 
patient had an LP, with cytology pending prior to discharge to 
evaluate for leptomeningeal spread. She will follow-up with 
radiation oncology on ___ to begin radiation.

#Hemorrhagic brain mets: ___ on admission showing numerous 
lesions concerning for mets with hemorrhage in R occipital lobe; 
repeat CT ___ showed stable hemorrhage reassuring against 
progressive bleed. MRI with multiple intracranial hemorrhagic 
lesions with suggestion of osseous involvement. Patient was 
started on keppra and dexamethasone. Neuro exam was significant 
for L visual field deficit but was otherwise within normal 
limits, and patient did not develop new neurological deficits 
while admitted. Per rad onc, treatment will be whole brain 
radiation vs. stereotactic radiosurgery vs neurosurgery, pending 
CSF cytology results from LP on ___. 

#Headache: Patient presented with acute worsening of weeks-long 
headache, likely ___ visualized likely metastatic lesions on CT. 
While she was admitted, pain was controlled with ___ mg PO 
dilaudid q4, with good effect.

#Metastatic breast CA: Per outpatient notes, patient had 
recently re-presented to ___ oncology after previous admission 
documented extensive thoracic mets. Prior to this presentation, 
plan had been to initiate capecitabine and screen for clinical 
trials. Dr. ___ is aware of this admission.

#Binge eating disorder: Continued topiramate

#HTN: Lisinopril was held given normal blood pressures

appointments

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for 
shortness of breath and headache. Unfortunately, a CT scan of 
your head showed that you had cancer that spread to your brain. 
An MRI also showed spread of your cancer to the brain. 
Radiation-Oncology, Neurosurgery, and Neuro-Oncology all 
evaluated you in the hospital. A lumbar puncture (LP) was 
performed to determine if there was any cancer in the fluid 
around your brain. Currently we are planning for your radiation 
as an outpatient and it is very important that you follow-up

-------------

unlikely to be coronary artery disease given that patient denies

on catheterization. It is possible that polycythemia ___ could

Sternal Precautions

laboratory monitoring required

Personal Care:
1. Remove dressings and discard. Dressings may be replaced as 
needed. Use tape sparingly.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with hydrogen peroxide.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.
5. You may shower daily, cover the wound and drain with seran 
wrap. shower with assistance as needed.
8. The Dermabond skin glue will begin to flake off in about ___ 
days.
9. No pressure on your chest or abdomen
10. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
surgeon
.
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.  Avoid caffeine and 
chocolate.
2. DO NOT drive for 3 weeks.
3. Sternal precautions
4. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery.
5. Please perform the occupational/physical therapy exercises as 
instructed.
.
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered .
2. No NSAIDs for one week. You may resume your baby aspirin 
seven days after discharge from the hospital.
3. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain.  You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength 
Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging.  Please note 
that Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient 
so do not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.
5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish.
7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness,swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
.
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain and strip the drain at the same 
time each day. Pull the stopper out of the drainage bottle and 
empty the drainage fluid into the measuring cup. Record the 
amount of drainage fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain 
suction.

The patient's medications at discharge include ezetimibe, levothyroxine, ranitidine, rosuvastatin, aspirin, docusate sodium, magnesium oxide, acetaminophen, lisinopril, amlodipine, clonidine, ipratropium-albuterol, oxycodone, metoprolol tartrate, furosemide, and nafcillin. She is also scheduled for weekly lab work, including Cr, BUN, T bili, Alt, Ast, Alk ph, wbc, Hct/Hgb. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 68-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after falling from a ladder and being found down. He was transferred from an outside hospital and was found to have bifrontal contusions and a 2.5mm subdural hematoma in the middle cranial fossa. The patient has a history of COPD, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, hiatal hernia, lower esophageal ring, BPH, prostate nodule, and colonic polyps. He has no known allergies to drugs.

The patient underwent PEG placement and IVC filter placement during his hospital stay. He was intubated and sedated initially, but was eventually extubated and transferred to the floor. He was found to have decreased movement in his lower extremities and was incontinent of bladder and bowels.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including docusate sodium, lansoprazole, phenytoin, warfarin, magnesium hydroxide, senna, insulin sliding scale, bisacodyl, and fluticasone-salmeterol. He was discharged to an extended care facility in a stable condition with a diagnosis of multiple hemorrhagic contusions and subdural hematoma. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY
===============
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with a past medical history
of rheumatoid arthritis on chronic prednisone, ESRD on ___ HD,
COPD on 2L home O2, recent episode of ESBL E. Coli bacteremia
___, completed treatment with Zosyn for 14 day course) who 
presented to ___ with 3 days of atraumatic right hip pain 
concerning for septic arthritis, likely seeded by her recurrence 
of her E. coli bacteremia. She was transferred to ___, treated 
with IV antibiotics, seen by ID, orthopedics, had a R hip MRI, 
and discharged on meropenem for 6 weeks with OPAT follow up.

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#ESBL E Coli bacteremia
Blood cultures positive from ___ and ED for GNRs. His 
cultures grew in recurrent ESBL E. Coli from ___, for which 
she already completed a course of zosyn x14d. TTE negative for 
vegetation. The source of the ESBL E Coli is unknown but we 
considered GI vs GU, given her history of rectal prolapse per 
her report (she had seen a colorectal surgeon at ___). 
Colorectal surgery saw her during this admission and firmly 
believed her ectropion was not an infectious source. The E Coli 
was sensitive to meropenem. ID was consulted and she was treated 
with IV meropenem for 6 week course. Her ___ blood culture was 
positive for gram-positive cocci in clusters, but this was 
speciated to coag negative staph and was likely a contaminant. 

#Leukocytosis: Initially elevated to ___ iso bacteremia as well 
chronic elevation from steroid use. Downtrending on discharge to 
baseline with treatment of bacteremia as above. Discharge WBC: 
16.8. 

#Septic Joint
Initially concerning for septic arthritis vs. trochanteric 
bursitis.
Atraumatic hip pain. Joint aspirate with 22K WBCs and Hct 22,
negative culture. However she had already received two days of 
antibiotics at the time of aspiration. She was seen by ortho, 
who thought her pain was likely trochanteric bursitis. GNRs 
would also be an atypical cause of septic arthritis, but the hip 
could have been seeded during her recent bacteremia. Rheum and 
ID both agreed with the diagnosis of a likely septic joint and 
recommend wash out, which was deferred by orthopedics. An MRI R 
hip was obtained notable for small effusion with no evidence of 
a septic joint. Rheumatology was concerned that she may not 
improve with antibiotics alone given the severity of her RA, 
however, the decision was made to treat the patient 
conservatively with IV antibiotics. Patient seemed to improve 
clinically with antibiotics with improved mobility at the joint 
so a wash-out was deferred in agreeance with all consulting 
services. She had a PICC line placed on ___ for continued 
antibiotics. 

#Incidental Uterine Mass
#Cervical stenosis
Incidentally found mass seen on her MRI of her R hip. She had a 
follow up pelvic US which showed a likely fibroid vs. polyp. The 
ultrasound also revealed a fluid filled uterine cavity 
concerning for cervical stenosis. The patient was asymptomatic. 
She will need outpatient gynecology follow-up. 

#ESRD on HD 
#Hyperkalemia
Initially became fluid overloaded and hyperkalemic in the 
setting of missing HD. Transferred to the ICU for 2 days until 
stabilized with emergent HD and returned to the floor. Her 
hyperkalemia was treated with insulin/Calcium. Discharge K 5.8 
after which she received HD. On MWF HD. Access: LUE AVF. 

#Macrocytic Anemia
Most likely secondary to ESRD. MCV 101-102. Folate normal. B12
low-normal 389. Recommend serum or urine MMA as outpatient to 
assess for B12 deficiency as a low normal B12 may still be 
deficient at the tissue level.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Hypertension. Remained hypertensive to 180s, but asymptomatic.
Her home regimen was continued as below: 
On HD days: Hydral 25 BID, labetalol 300 BID
On non-HD days: Hydral 25 TID, labetalol 300 TID, amlodipine 10
On all days: Lisinopril 10
Her lisinopril was increased to 20 mg po daily in light of 
continued high blood pressures. 

#Rheumatoid arthritis 
Initially give 10 mg prednisone po daily and titrated down to 
7.5 mg as per rheumatology recs. 

#COPD on 2L home O2 
There is some concern that her respiratory disease is actually
due to ILD in the setting of her RA. Could consider PFTs as an
outpatient. She received O2 and her home nebulizers

#Hypothyroidism 
She was continued on levothyroxine 125 mcg daily. 

#Anxiety/depression 
She was continued on her home pregabalin, clonazepam, sertraline 
and trazodone.

She has a history of atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and congestive heart failure. She was previously taking coumadin, but it was stopped due to recurrent rectal bleeding. The patient underwent a hemorrhoidectomy and was found to have internal hemorrhoids. She was also diagnosed with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, severe aortic stenosis, mitral regurgitation, obstructive sleep apnea, and congestive heart failure.

The patient's medications at discharge include amiodarone, allopurinol, simvastatin, vitamin D3, nitroglycerin, docusate sodium, calcium carbonate, metoprolol succinate, valsartan, and furosemide. She was instructed to restart coumadin once spotting resolves and to follow up with her doctor and cardiologist as an outpatient.

The patient was discharged home with stable vital signs, controlled pain, and tolerating a diet. She was advised to take all of her medications as usual and to not restart coumadin or aspirin until she sees her doctor in clinic next week. ||endoftext||

She has had recent complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath, which have been worsening over time. She underwent right and left cardiac catheterization, which showed mild LVH with preserved ejection fraction. She was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and underwent cardiac catheterization to evaluate for left main disease prior to surgery. At discharge, she was prescribed medications and advised to follow up with her cardiologist.

Relevant past medical history includes spinal stenosis, fibromyalgia/polymyalgia rheumatica, hypertension, osteoarthritis, depression, and s/p bilateral oopherectomy. She has allergies to Aspirin, Ultram, Vioxx, Percocet, Vicodin, and Cephalexin.

The patient's physical examination revealed a slightly distant S1, S2 with no appreciable M/R/G, and no chest wall deformities, scoliosis, or kyphosis. Her abdomen was soft, non-tender, and non-distended, and her extremities showed non-pitting 1+ lower extremity edema, symmetric, and no calf tenderness.

Pertinent lab results include a glucose level of 153* on admission and 133* at discharge, with a normal white blood cell count and platelet count. Her chest X-ray showed lower lung volumes and fullness of indistinct pulmonary vessels consistent with elevated pulmonary venous pressure. ||endoftext||

Neurologically stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed. If your wound closure uses dissolvable sutures, 
you must keep that area dry for 10 days. 
You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to.

___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

1. Urinary retention - POD1 foley removed and patient unable to 
void, straight cath x 1, failed voiding trial again, foley 
replaced POD1 eve and removed again on POD3, voising trial 
pending.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the 
surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without 
erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by 
physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital 
course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the 
patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's 
hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on 
an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly 
intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.
 
She is discharged to rehab in stable condition.

sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
removed will be taken out at your follow-up visit in three (3) 
weeks after your surgery.

7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.

8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.  
___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.

10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
visit in three (3) weeks.

11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.

12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Physical Therapy:
LLE WBAT
Unrestricted ROM
CPM ___ at maximum flexion
Mobilize
Treatments Frequency:
DSD daily prn drainage
Wound checks
Ice and elevation
TEDs
*Staples will be removed in 3 weeks at followup appt*

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext||The patient is a 72-year-old female who was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service for a left total knee arthroplasty. She has a history of advancing osteoarthritis of the left knee, and has tried symptomatic treatment including injections and physical therapy without relief. Her past medical history includes hyperlipidemia, anxiety, depression, diabetes type II, colon cancer, benign thyroid nodule, and sciatica. She has no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis is left knee degenerative joint disease. She underwent an uncomplicated surgery and tolerated the procedure well. Her postoperative course was marked by urinary retention, which was managed with a foley catheter. She was also treated with lovenox for DVT prophylaxis and received pain medication as needed.

At discharge, the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. Her vital signs were stable, and her hematocrit was acceptable. She was discharged to rehab with instructions to follow up with her primary physician and to resume her home medications unless otherwise instructed. ||endoftext||

Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed man with a history of

and then again on ___ due to the persistent myalgias. At that

lasting

Basic labs were all normal and he was advised to monitor his

However over the next week his vertigo persisted, still only
brought on by movement, and he also began to notice weakness in
his left arm and leg. He initially attributed this to the muscle

the

control his left arm and leg. He says they feel weak but also
clumsy, and his arm "flops around" when he tries to use it. His
wife says he also veers toward the left when he walks, and his
left leg has "given out" on him a couple of times. He has fallen
twice in the last week, once when getting out of the car and 
then
again yesterday when he was trying to help his wife make up the
bed. Both times his left leg just seemed to buckle and he fell 
to
the ground, sustaining some scrapes but no significant injuries.
Last night he was playing cards with his friends, which he has
done for ___ years, and realized that he couldn't hold the cards
or shuffle with his left hand. At this point he became 
concerned,

- NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT (___): Findings concerning for multiple

COMMENT: The appearance of the intracranial and calvarial

CT ___ W CONTRAST (___):  
1. Multiple enlarged low-attenuation mediastinal lymph nodes and

2. A 1.5 cm and 1.6 cm hypodense lesions in segment 2 and 4B 
nonspecific but suspicious for hepatic metastasis, especially

muscle,

guidance, if necessary. 
4. Enlarged necrotic lymph nodes at the left external iliac and 
left common iliac chain, suspicious for nodal metastases. 
5. Cholelithiasis. Small hiatal hernia. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo RH M with a history of prostate CA s/p radiation, 
hyperlipidemia, cervical spine disease, and tobacco use who 
presents with left sided weakness and incoordination over the 
last 10 days. In the ED, head CT showed 3 lesions with central 
hemorrhage/necrosis and vasogenic edema in the left frontal 
lobe, left parietal lobe, and most notably in the left 
cerebellar vermis coming close to impinging on the ___ 
ventricle, with no hydrocephalus. CTA head/neck incidentally 
revealed a mass in the right upper lung with adjacent necrotic 
lymph nodes. The findings were highly concerning for metastatic 
cancer. 

# HOSPITAL COURSE: He was admitted to the Neurology service for 
further workup. MRI brain confirmed presence of hemorrhagic 
metastases in the left frontal and parietal lobes and left 
cerebellar hemisphere with small amount of vasogenic edema. CT 
torso revealed multiple lesions concerning for metastatic cancer 
-- enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes, 1.4cm RUL nodule and 
multiple other pulmonary nodules, 2 liver lesions, solid lesion 
posterior to the left psoas, and enlarged necrotic left iliac 
lymph nodes. Given his smoking history and distribution of the 
lesions, findings were highly suspicious for metastatic lung 
cancer. 

The next day an endobronchial biopsy of the right lung and LNs 
was obtained by Interventional Pulmonology (results pending on 
discharge). Hematology-Oncology, Neuro-Oncology, Neurosurgery 
and Radiation Oncology services consulted for workup and 
planning. Given the size of the cerebellar mass and its close 
proximity to the ___ ventricle, it was felt that patient would 
need whole brain radiation (fractionated radiotherapy to the 
area would cause too much swelling and thus hydrocephalus, and 
surgical resection would be unsafe given his age and 
comorbidities). After much debate, it was decided that he needed 
EVD placed before beginning whole brain XRT since risk for 
subsequent edema and hydrocephalus was still high. This will be 
performed one week after discharge, on ___ -- 
patient will be called beforehand with time and name of 
neurosurgeon doing the procedure. Following EVD placement, he 
will see Radiation Oncology (Dr. ___ in clinic to begin 
planning for whole-brain radiation. They anticipate beginning 
XRT one week after surgery in order to allow superficial wound 
healing. 

Patient was started on Dexamethasone 4mg qAM (with GI 
prophylaxis) in the hospital for additional for additional 
protection against vasogenic edema. He was also given oxycodone 
on discharge for left hip pain caused by metastases to the area, 
which cause him significant discomfort. 

At the time of discharge, results of the lung biopsy are still 
pending. Once they return, Heme-Onc will coordinate follow up 
and planning for systemic therapy in the appropriate clinic 
(most likely Thoracic Oncology, given high suspicion that this 
is lung cancer). 

Patient was seen by Social Work in the hospital to address 
coping with his new diagnosis and for assistance obtaining 
long-term disability and transportation to future appointments 
at ___. 

====================
TRANSITIONS OF CARE:
- Studies pending = lung biopsy from ___ (to be followed up by 
Heme Onc)
- Needs to be called by Neurosurgery and Rad Onc departments to 
schedule EVD placement and XRT planning in next week

finger movements on left, mildly wide based gait. 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital for new clumsiness and 
weakness on the left side of your body. An MRI of your brain 
showed 3 masses concerning for metastatic cancer, one of which 
was in an area called the CEREBELLUM and carries a high risk for 
causing brain cancer (HYDROCEPHALUS). A subsequent CT scan of 
your torso showed masses in your lymph nodes, lungs and liver 
also concerning for cancer. A lung biopsy was performed, results 
pending. 

The next step in your care will be to start whole brain 
radiation. Before this, you will need a ventriculo-peritoneal 
(VP) shunt. This will be done on ___. You will 
be called by the Neurosurgery apartment with the name of the 
surgeon who will perform the operation and the time of surgery. 

Approximately 3 days after shunt placement, you should attend 
your follow-up appointment with Radiation Oncology. They will 
coordination your radiation plan, as well as your follow-up 
appointments with Neuro-Oncology (___). You will be 
called by them to schedule this appointment in the next few 
days.

You are scheduled for an outpatient with Medical Oncology (Dr. 
___ on ___ to discuss the results of your lung 
biopsy, which should have returned by them. See below for more 
info. They will plan your systemic therapy (chemotherapy and/or 
radiation) once the lung biopsy results have returned. 

We made the following changes to your medications: 
1. STARTED Dexamethasone (Decadron) 4mg by mouth in AM -- this 
is to treat swelling of the brain due to cancer. 
2. STARTED Famotidine 20mg twice daily -- this is to prevent 
acid reflux caused by Decadron. 
3. STARTED Oxycodone 2.5-5mg every 6 hrs as needed for pain -- 
side effects include nausea and constipation. Can take over the 
counter laxative as needed.
4. STARTED Ondansetron (Zofran) 4mg every 8 hrs as needed for 
nausea -- if experienced as side effect of oxycodone.

Moderate to severe pulmonary edema.  Retrocardiac opacity may
